stork.feather

Class Resource<S extends Session,R extends Resource>

  • java.lang.Object
    • stork.feather.Resource<S,R>
  • Type Parameters:
    S - The type of Session that can operate on this Resource.
    R - The supertype of all Resources this Resource can be selected from or produce through selection. Generally, for a subclass, this is the subclass itself.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FTPResource, Resources.Anonymous

    public class Resource<S extends Session,R extends Resource>
extends java.lang.Object
    A virtual representation of a physical resource. The resource(s) represented by a Resource object may be a single resource (such as a file or directory) or a set thereof (such as a directory tree or files matching a pattern). The existence of a Resource object does not guarantee the existence or accessibility of the resource(s) it represents. In particular, creating a Resource object does not

    A Resource instance may be selected through a Session, in which case it is said to be active. Operations performed on an active Resource are performed in the context of the associated Session. If a Resource is not parented to a Session, the Resource is said to be inert. An inert Resource must be selected through a Session to be operated on.

    A Resource should be thought of as a placeholder for or reference to a physical resource, with a Session as the entity responsible for providing access it to the concrete resource(s) it represents. A Resource object should not have any allocation state associated with it. Instead, such state should be maintained by the Session the Resource is selected through.

    In general, a Resource represents a selection path from a top-level Resource (typically a Session) to one or many Resources representing subresources. This top-level Resource is known as the root. If a Resource represents exactly one physical resource, it is called a singleton Resource. The trunk of a Resource is the first singleton Resource encountered when traversing backwards to the root.

    All of the methods specified by this interface should return immediately. In the case of methods that return Bells, the result should be determined asynchronously and given to the caller through the returned Bell. Implementations that do not support certain operations are allowed to throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

    See Also:
    Session

    • Method Detail

      • session

        public S session()
        Get the Session this Resource is selected on.
        Returns:
        The Session associated with this resource, or null if it is an inert Resource.

      • name

        public java.lang.String name()
        Get the name of this Resource. This may be null if this is a root Resource.
        Returns:
        The name of this Resource.

      • root

        public final R root()
        Return the root Resource of this Resource. That is, the Resource in the hierarchy that has no parent. For an active Resource, this is the same as called session(). For an inert Resource, this will return the top-level Resource. The root Resource is always a singleton.
        Returns:
        This Resource's root Resource.

      • isRoot

        public final boolean isRoot()
        Return whether or not this is a root Resource.
        Returns:
        true if this is a root Resource; false otherwise.

      • isActive

        public final boolean isActive()
        Check if this Resource is active. That is, check that its root is a Session. An active Resource may have operations performed on it. This does not mean that the Resource is initialized or that the resource is represents exists.
        Returns:
        true if the Resource is active; false otherwise.

      • isInert

        public final boolean isInert()
        Check if this Resource is inert. This returns true if and only if isActive() returns false. An inert Resource must be selected through a Session in order to have have operations performed on it.
        Returns:
        true if the Resource is inert; false otherwise.

      • trunk

        public final Resource trunk()
        Return the trunk of this Resource. That is, the first singleton Resource encountered when traversing back to the root. Or, in other words, the first Resource such that all segments in the selection Path are non-glob segments.
        Returns:
        The first singleton ancestor of this Resource.

      • isSingleton

        public final boolean isSingleton()
        Check if this is a singleton Resource. That is, a Resource that identifies exactly one physical resource.
        Returns:
        true if this is a singleton Resource; false otherwise.

      • subresources

        public Bell<> subresources()
        Get the sub-resources of this Resource. Specifically, this returns a mapping from Resource names as Strings to Resources. This can only be called on a singleton Resource and returns null if it is not a singleton Resource. It may also return null either from the method or through the returned Bell if this Resource does not represent a collection resource.
        Returns:
        (via bell) A mapping from names to Resources that represent sub-resources of this Resource.

      • reselectOn

        public R reselectOn(S session)
        Reselect this Resource through an equivalent Session. Assuming session is actually equivalent to this Resource's Session, the returned Resource will refer to the same physical resource. This can, for instance, be used to select the same resource through an already established session.

        If this Resource is already selected through session (or is null and this Resource is inert), this Resource is returned as-is.

        If resource is null, an inert equivalent

        Parameters:
        session - the session to reselect this resource on.
        Returns:
        An equivalent Resource which can be accessed through session.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if session is not equivalent to this Resource's Session.

      • uri

        public URI uri()
        Get a URI associated with this resource.
        Returns:
        A URI which identifies this resource.

      • wrap

        public <T> Relative<R,T> wrap(Path path,
                     T object)
        Wrap an object with a Relative with this Resource as the root.

      • initialize

        public final Bell<S> initialize()
        Initialize the Session associated with this Resource to perform operations on this Resource. Implementors should call this themselves in the method body of any operation that requires Session initialization (for example, a control channel connection) to ensure that the associated Session is ready to perform operations on this Resource. This can also be used outside the framework to "warm up" the Resource in anticipation of future use. The returned Bell will ring when initialization is complete, indicating that Resource implementations are allowed to perform the operation through the Session.

        Until finalize() has been called, subsequent calls to this method will have no effect and will always return the same Bell. Once the Resource has been finalized, this method can be called again to re-initialize the Resource.

        This method has no effect if the Resource is inert, and returns null.

        Returns:
        (via bell) The associated Session once it has been initialized to operate on this Resource, unless the Resource is inert. If it is insert, this method returns a Bell already rung with null.

      • finalize

        public final void finalize()
        Finalize any state Session associated with this Resource may have allocated in order to initialize this Resource. This method has no effect unless this Resource has been initialized and has not yet been finalized. This is also called when the Resource is garbage collected, though calling it manually before garbage collection is the preferred way of freeing any state associated with the Resource if it is known to no longer be needed.

        This method has no effect if the Resource is inert.

        Overrides:
        finalize in class java.lang.Object

      • stat

        public Bell<Stat> stat()
        Get metadata for this resource, which includes a list of subresources.
        Returns:
        (via bell) A Stat containing resource metadata.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - (via bell) if there was an error retrieving metadata for the resource.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if metadata retrieval is not supported.

      • mkdir

        public Bell mkdir()
        Create this resource as a directory on the storage system. If the resource cannot be created, or already exists and is not a directory, the returned Bell will be resolved with an Exception.
        Returns:
        (via bell) null if successful.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - (via bell) if the directory could not be created or already exists and is not a directory.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if creating directories is not supported.

      • unlink

        public Bell unlink()
        Delete the Resource from the storage system. If the resource cannot be removed, the returned Bell will be resolved with an Exception.
        Returns:
        (via bell) null if successful.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - (via bell) if the resource could not be fully removed.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if removal is not supported.

      • select

        public abstract R select(java.lang.String name)
        Select a subresource by name relative to this resource. By default, this simply appends name to the URI of this resource. Subclasses may override this to introduce special behavior.
        Parameters:
        name - the unescaped name of a subresource to select.
        Returns:
        A subresource of this resource.

      • select

        public final R select(Path path)
        Select a subresource relative to this resource using the given path.
        Parameters:
        path - the path to the subresource, relative to this resource.
        Returns:
        A subresource relative to this resource.

      • selectRelative

        public final RelativeResource selectRelative(Path path)
        Select a subresource as a RelativeResource containing relative path information. This is used during proxy transfers, and should generally not be used in applications unless maintaining relative path information across selection is necessary.
        Parameters:
        path - the path to the subresource, relative to this resource.
        Returns:
        A subresource relative to this Resource containing a reference to this Resource.

      • path

        public Path path()
        Get the selection path of this Resource relative to the root.
        Returns:
        The selection path of this Resource relative to the root.

      • transferTo

        public Transfer transferTo( resource)
        Initiate a transfer from this Resource to resource using whatever method is deemed most appropriate by the implementation. The implementation should try to transfer the resource as efficiently as possible, and so should inspect the destination resource to determine if more efficient alternatives to proxy transferring can be done. This method should perform a proxy transfer as a catch-all last resort.
        Parameters:
        resource - the destination resource to transfer this resource to
        Returns:
        A Transfer on success. The returned Transfer object can be used to control and monitor the transfer.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the direction of transfer is not supported by one of the resources.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if resource is null.

      • sink

        public Sink sink()
        Open a sink to the resource. Any connection operation, if necessary, should begin as soon as this method is called.
        Returns:
        A sink which drains to the named resource.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - (via bell) if opening the sink fails.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the resource does not support writing.

      • tap

        public Tap tap()
        Open a tap on the resource. Any connection operation, if necessary, should begin, as soon as this method is called.
        Returns:
        (via bell) A tap which emits slices from this resource and its subresources.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - (via bell) if opening the tap fails.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the resource does not support reading.
